poem:
**The Maternal Map**

Here, neurons sketch nova patterns,
a celestial choreography across grey matter.
Time-lapse tales of love and light,
echoes of origins, reshaped, reborn.
In these cerebral caverns, futures forge,
bleeding permanence and ephemera alike,
each synapse a silver thread weaved
in the vast tapestry of life, mother and child
bound by biological constellations.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Scans capture sweeping reorganisation of brain in pregnancy Profound changes that sweep across the human brain during pregnancy have been captured for the first time, after researchers performed precision scans on a woman carrying her child. MRI scans taken every few weeks from before conception until two years after childbirth revealed widespread reorganisation in the mother’s brain, with some changes short-lived and others lasting years. The work, described as “truly heroic” by one independent expert,". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
